Posted By: Martin_the_Warrior (12/30/2008 11:19:13 AM)
Rating:

posts.post_content: I'd like to say he's overrated since he represents all that I hate about competitive magic (playing monoblack aggro? +4 [Bayou](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Bayou), +4 goyf, or go home kid!) but Tarmogoyf is brutally powerful. He's not always an auto-include imo, as he's \*just\* going to be a 2/3 in an average deck. For most decks though, particularly in the grave abuse of extended, he's a 3/4 or 4/5 and is a necessary weapon. Also, he goes together with the 2nd best 2-drop of all time ([Wild Mongrel](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Wild Mongrel))like Peanut Butter and Jelly :)
posts.html:
I'd like to say he's overrated since he represents all that I hate about competitive magic (playing monoblack aggro? +4 Bayou, +4 goyf, or go home kid!) but Tarmogoyf is brutally powerful. He's not always an auto-include imo, as he's *just* going to be a 2/3 in an average deck. For most decks though, particularly in the grave abuse of extended, he's a 3/4 or 4/5 and is a necessary weapon. Also, he goes together with the 2nd best 2-drop of all time (Wild Mongrel)like Peanut Butter and Jelly :)

posts.post_content: A great 2-drop (if not the greatest), even if it was a total mistake. It will be used in all formats it is legal in until the end of Magic. Tarmogoyf fills many roles: A quick aggro beater, a protected control finisher, or a wall... for other Tarmogoyfs.

Posted By: Mortisss (11/16/2008 3:39:25 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content: This card shows how much big dumb green fatties have to be pushed in order to be playable. Now that it has been printed and they can never print a bigger, cheaper green creature, they can focus on making other green creatures that have abilities that matter. Considering that green is the colour with the "best creatures", the fact that this card was an accident shows that green creature design still has a long way to go.
posts.html:
